Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2009 02:41PM QueenK wrote: Okay..yipee for the brilliant description of a sentinal node, NOT applying to breast cancer. The sentinal node is the gateway node, if that one is cancerous POSSIBLY others are as well.Please do NOT USE THE WORD METASTATIC...this means terror in breast cancer patients.You can have a positive lymph node and have it not go anywhere.It can, and sometimes is just that node. Stop misinforming people. To people with breast cancer the word "metastatic means it has moved around, usually to the organs.Gawd.

That said if my breast had a huge lump and was red and my nipple was black, I would sit in the ER until someone saw me or threw me in the looney bin, seriously..I would and HAVE (so please do not try and tell me I have not been through this) made a stink until SOMEONE listened. So what in the WORLD? is this gyno waiting for??? Seriously.I do not know of any gyno that would be that stupid to sit on that and wait.

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2009 12:32AM QueenK wrote: Are you KIDDING me? No you are kidding yourself.Why, oh why after having gone through breast cancer would you use a taning bed? And what are you thinking they don't cause skin cancer? I can't cut and paste in firefox but here this is from an article that was written from cancer.org. The world health organization states that tanning beds should NOT be used for tanning or NON medical purposes.A  2005 study  links skin cancer with the use of tanning beds.An 8 year International study says that woman who used tanning beds where 55% more likely to develop malignant melanoma than woman who did not artificially suntan. Do not for a minute believe what a tanning place tells you about this being safer than sun.You are playing with your life here.That is the most uneducated and naive thing I have ever heard.

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2008 01:15PM QueenK wrote: I had an "open" excisional on a duct that was pretty far back.I was put right under, and I have inside stitches and steri strips, the incision is about 5 inches long,mine was from a bleeding nipple so it HAD to come out anyway. I do know we all are sharing our experiences here.Please remember we all have different pain thresh holds.I was give morphine injections right after and tylenol 3's to take home which I did take.Although I cannot take advil as I am allergic. So there are lots on here saying it was not painful enough to warrent meds, but sometimes it is.Never refuse an RX for meds as you may need them.My Dr also said some people only need tylenol and I am not one of those people!
Posts.Title: Have you had an excisional biopsy? What can i expect? erin1 leaf

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2008 06:56PM QueenK wrote: Well they do call it a cancer center cause thats what it is.That said I had bleeding from my nipple and it took me months and months to be diagnosed.I never had blood taken to see if it was an infection I find that a very odd and very not neccesary step in my opinion.As a matter of fact it is very unlikely it would be an infection... That said, I was told it could be a papilomma (a small "wart" in the duct). hardening of the ducts (very unlikely in someone my age 32). or cancer.They say 80% of the time it is NOT cancer, then again that is talk about a lump and not discharge. You could have a mammogram, a ductal proble, an ultrasound.I had an excision and mine was cancer.TRY not to freak out...it could really be anything. BTW I had stage 1, grade 2 BC and mine was 1.7 MM's.I had a lumpectomy and radiation and I am FINE.I have been told that with discharge if it is cancer it is usually smaller. You will be FINE either way..:)

Posts.Title: Mam, US result and Rant about waiting thisisme Beesie

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2008 08:20AM QueenK wrote: I am not going to get into this TOO much but I think the canadian health care system is tragically flawed.Please understand not everyone lives in Alberta, where health care is top notch and not everyone can get into princess maragaret or any of those other places in Toronto.I live about 45 minutes away from toronto but because of transportation and waiting issues I was not able to go there.I did get good treatment where I live but it was not top notch. I had waiting period from 1 week to 3 months for my diagnostic tests and surgeries.I was wait listed more times than you could count.From the day I had bloody discharge until my diagnosis it was 11 months and 14 days.Most of that time was spent waiting for tests and pathology which took thir sweet time. Anyone can google and see the sad state of health care in ontario.I often think that people that live in toronto live in a bubble.You could not count the number of times I have heard "Well my 80 year old aunt just zipped into princess maragret and got all fixed up" thats nice.Ontario is a HUGE province! the younger you are the less yyou are taken seriously.My 2 cents.
Posts.Title: Mam, US result and Rant about waiting thisisme Beesie

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2008 04:01PM QueenK wrote: Super post.But I was not talking about the US system.I didn't even mention it actually.But if I had the money I for sure would have gone to the one day diagnostic clinic while I was on vacation in tennessee.In hindsight I would have had my father wire me the money.What happened to me and countless other people where I am is NOT excusable. Partially it has to do with my age.My 60 yr old mother was rushed in to get a diagnostic mammogram and I had to wait.Hers turned out to be a begnign condition. Hate your Dr? Too bad.We are in an understaffed province and area and so even if I hated him I could not change Drs.You get who you get and thats it.I had to wait for radiation, I am living in pain every single day and cannot get pain meds. FYI I lived in the states for 2 years and I also know that system.I was VERY lucky my dad had goodinsurance.I had some pretty bad medical problems but the treatment was swift and prompt.I just really hate that people think Canada is this utopia of awesome medical care.If you live in the right place, and know the right people...maybe. I also do pay for my healthcare, through very high taxes.I also pay for my medication out of pocket.Very true I am LUCKY as heck because I don't get a bill after tests/procedures.I chose to go to buffalo for my MRI, the wait time here was 3 months.Turns out I didn't have the luxury of time. Am I angry? Yes very.
Posts.Title: Mam, US result and Rant about waiting thisisme Beesie

Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 05:08PM QueenK wrote: I had the same idea.I will explain something. Here in canada, we have the so called "guidelines" from Cancer Care Ontario,I was told and without my permission set up for all these tests.According to cancer care ontario, and many other places these tests are NOT needed in Stage 1 cancer with no node involvement. I waited until I saw my oncologist and put the tests on hold.He told me that many surgeons, oncologists like to triple check and make sure there are NOT any more problems.However, he did not think I needed to put myself through the extra trauma, there are many problems with these tests and very often you will get a false positive, requiring more stress and painful tests. Armed with this info from my oncologist (who also happens to be a world class breast cancer researcher) I declined the tests. That said... I know many woman that WANT to do the scans.I myself have been told I am in denial, I consider myself informed.I did my research. Your Dr terrified you, when I found out that this was not "protocal" and was only the surgeons personal way of handling things.I went and talked to her about the unneeded stress and anxiety.My oncologist also forwarded a letter signed by himself and his associate outlining the guidelines. Anyway...
Posts.Title: Is my doctor keeping something from me I should know? happytobealive happytobealive

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 11:16PM QueenK wrote: How important is a rads onc? Well mine thinks he is god..so i dumped him.I am now done radiation and will be only too pleased never to see him again.There is a school of thought that sometimes if you are seeing your other Drs..they become not so important. The 1st thing he ever said to me "I want you to consider a mast, it may be genetic" I called my med onc and surgeon in TEARS.They calmed me down.I have DD breasts and had 1.5 cm HUGE margins and less than 2mm cancer.

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2008 01:11AM QueenK wrote: Ok the first procedure is a ductogram, totally useless in my situation and very rarely helpful.I had a duct excision and they removed one duct, the one that had the blood in it.The other ducts where left alone...until. I found out it was cancer, then they did a lumpectomy and then my breast became not so pleasing looking.I have a huge dent and my nipple is all wonky LOL But if the discharge has stopped then maybe its nothing.Good vibes :) BTW after my duct excision I lost sensation.
Posts.Title: Pending Duct Excision.....PLEASE HELP Rene48 Grannyx2

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2009 07:45PM QueenK wrote: I find it very interesting and a little misleading that not just on this board, but on other boards as well that the people who find canadian health care SO wonderful are often from Toronto.Toronto is I am sure a great place to live if you have major health issues.Although some torontonians think that toronto represents ontario wholly this is not true. If you live in NFLD and Labrador you will wait for tests, MRI's, screening exams.Sometimes for months on end.Forger about getting test results fast, they fired a bunch of pathologists for reading the slides wrong and misdiagnosing BREAST cancer of all things. It is not just the east coast.I live in southwestern ontario and have the same problems.I live in an underserviced area where 20,000 ppl are on waiting lists for a family doctor. In my case, I waited 3 months for a consult to get the duct that was BLEEDING removed.Much of my time was spent waiting in the year it took me to get diagnosed.I waited for path results, am now waiting to get the BRCA test.The BRCA test was ordered in JULY and I am finally getting the blood drawn in FEBRUARY.And I am a person that has breast cancer,I may have messed up my chances of having reconstruction if I get a mast if the test is +..which brings me to.... I was told if I wanted a Mast, that I could not get immediate reconstruction because they would not be able to get a PS and a surgeon together OR I could wait 4 months. Anyway, I also don't agree. BIRADS 3 must be taken VERY seriously and not brushed off. Not everyone has the resources that Beesie had.We cannot all go to Princess Margaret and get top notch care.Wouldn't that be nice?

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2008 01:36PM QueenK wrote: Personally, I am not sure of what I think of the whole Christina Applegate thing.I like her, I do admire her that she came out and told her story,FYI she never said she had DCIS.She had TWO lumpectomies and was not able to get clear margins.I also did not have DCIS and did not have to do chemo, I did rads and that is it and I was stage one.I wished if anything I would have had DCIS. She is also in her early 30's.I am not knocking anyone on here,I have no idea of your ages but as someone diagnosed with breast cancer just out of my 20's I can tell you I was VERY angry.I had to make the decision as to try to have children, would I see them grow up, would I live until my 35th birthday? I have not been through as much as some of you, but please this is not a "whos a hero competition" I had virtually no support...from friends, barely any from family.I had 2 surgeries in 6 weeks, radiation and now??? I have been told I am cancer free.I certainly hope I am not being naieve in saying I will not die of breast cancer.Truth be told, no one was there when her Dr and her discussed things, no one knows her prognosis, or how serious her cancer was. By documenting my struggle above,I in no way compare myself to anyone else.We each struggle, and we each deal with it in our own way. Myself, I had had some complications, so no matter how "easy" my journey and radiation may have seemed to some of you..I can tell you its not.There are some people such as myself who don't "go into the office daily" and I am OK with that...anyway....

The nurse brushed me off, she said they never give anything stronger and I could try tylenol 1's that have 8 mg codeine, OTC in canada.Guess what?? Not helping one bit. Posts.Title: Question for those who have had bloody nipple discharge curiousgeorgia barbe1958

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2009 10:39PM QueenK wrote: Okay 1st off this is a breast cancer board, so lots of people on here have ...breast cancer..its true!  Secondly, I would never ever wait again.I was 32 when I was diagnosed and this may be scary for you, but I was told I had mastitis (umm I don't have a baby), a breast infection three times and then I was told it was hormonal. Things like duct ectasia are quite common in older woman, as told to me by my surgeon.A papilloma is also possible as well.So yes "they" can say chances are its not cancer.But in reality in MY situation I was told by an oncologist that these are symptoms of cancer and not the other 2 conditions listed. 1.Bloody nipple discharge that comes out on its own. 2.nipple discharge from ONLY one nipple. 3.Yellow, brown and eventually red. the ONLY reason I am saying this, is you have to be pro active.Please know that I did have an ok mammogram, an okay ductogram and an ok ultrasound.They where all perfectly fine. There is a fine line between being really freaked out, and being rational.I was misdiagnosed for a whole year.I am not saying these things to frighten you, but I did not know until I had it removed, no lump, no anything.
Posts.Title: Question for those who have had bloody nipple discharge curiousgeorgia barbe1958

I got in the car and drove to a friends house, who called the office and reamed them out.These are the things I feel I can never get over.
